title: How to Have the Inheritance Talk With Older Parents
text:
My parents are well into their 80s and have never discussed their estate/inheritance plan with me or my siblings. I’m not even sure if there is a plan. How can I broach this?

I can empathize. I recall, after my father died, trying to convince my mother that she needed to update her decades-old will and related documents. This took a good year or two; she simply didn’t want to talk about it. So, starting a conversation like this can be difficult at best. Two approaches might help.

First, try telling your parents that you would like to talk with them about their estate plan—not because you want to know what, or how much, you might inherit, but because you want to make sure the transfer of their assets goes as smoothly as possible after they die. After all, you or one of your siblings, in all likelihood, will be responsible for carrying out your parents’ wishes.

If you think that approach is too blunt, try this: Tell your parents that you’re doing your own estate planning, and the more you know about the family’s finances as a whole, the better job you can do. It certainly wouldn’t hurt to mention that your children—your parents’ grandchildren—will benefit from such preparations. (It’s an argument a grandparent might find hard to resist.)

And please: If you or any of your siblings are interested in inheriting a particular item or heirloom, a sit-down with your parents is even more important. At times, the smallest objects—a watch, a painting, a set of dishes—can generate the biggest fights among heirs.

Again, I recognize that conversations about money are difficult for many families. And conversations about death can be even more difficult. If there’s a silver lining here, your attempts to talk about estate plans may prod your parents to make an appointment with their lawyer to spell out their wishes more clearly. Knowing that your parents have a will in place, at the very least, and that they have met with their lawyer in the past few years can give you some peace of mind.

Finally, let me open this topic to our readers: If a particular approach has worked for you when it comes to talking with older family members about finances and estate plans, please write us at askencore@wsj.com. We’ll do our best to get your thoughts into a future column.

***

I have almost all of my retirement assets, except Social Security, in Vanguard funds and believe they provide diversification. Should I transfer a portion of my Vanguard assets to another company, such as Fidelity or T. Rowe Price ? I think it unlikely that Vanguard would encounter a Bernie Madoff-type situation, but I have concerns about having most of my investment eggs in one basket.

I shared this question with several financial advisers, and their answers were invariably the same: Not to worry.

“Vanguard is one of the largest global investment firms, and there are numerous provisions in place to protect client assets,” says Charlie Farrell, chief executive officer of Northstar Investment Advisors in Denver.

Still, as we have mentioned many times in this column, the best investment plans are those that allow you to sleep soundly at night. With that in mind, “if a single account really bothers an investor, there is nothing wrong with having another account at a large custodian,” Mr. Farrell adds. “It’s just a little more of a hassle.”

Friends of mine are having a debate. Some of us are under the impression that the level of coverage for Medicare might be affected by the state/jurisdiction where you first enroll. So, here’s my question: Does it matter in which state your first enrollment occurs? If so, which states are more advantageous?

It doesn’t matter where you live if you decide to enroll in traditional Medicare; your coverage for Part A (hospital bills) and Part B (doctors’ bills) would be the same. But…the state where you live, as well as a move between states, could affect other pieces of the Medicare puzzle.

Start with Medicare Advantage, an alternative to traditional Medicare, and Medicare Part D, prescription-drug benefits. Both types of coverage are provided by private insurers, as opposed to the federal government. As such, these plans—their cost, availability and benefits—vary from state to state. What’s more, if you move to a new state, your existing Medicare Advantage or Part D plan may no longer cover you, which would mean searching for new insurance.

Photo: iStock

Then there’s Medicare Supplement Insurance, better known as Medigap. Such policies, which help pay bills that Medicare doesn’t cover, also are sold by private insurers and are regulated primarily by individual states. The good news here: Some states are more lenient than others when it comes to enrolling in, or changing, a Medigap policy, says Neil Brown, a Medicare insurance consultant in Las Vegas.

For example, under federal guidelines, individuals who enroll in Medicare Part B have six months to sign up for a Medigap policy regardless of any health problems. After that window closes, insurers in most states can place restrictions on coverage due to pre-existing conditions. But if you’re a resident of Missouri, for example, you have a two-month period each year in which you can switch insurers without penalty if you keep the same level of coverage.

The larger point: You should familiarize yourself with the rules governing Medicare Advantage, prescription-drug plans and Medigap policies in your particular state before buying coverage. A good starting point: “State-specific Medicare information” at Medicareresources.org. (At the top of the home page, click on: States.) Again, with Medigap in particular, some states, Mr. Brown notes, “might be considered more advantageous because they enable enrollment in Medigap well beyond the federally mandated period.”

Mr. Ruffenach is a former reporter and editor for The Wall Street Journal. His column examines financial issues for those thinking about, planning and living their retirement. Send questions and comments to askencore@wsj.com.
